reviewText:
The game is really dull; simplified to the point that even people who haven't played Zelda or FF would be turned away from sheer boredom. The game touts it's gameplay and the ability to visually travel through gaming history, through the styles of Zelda, Final Fantasy, Diablo and more. But the game leans so heavily upon it's gimmicks that when the gimmicks don't pan out, the game collapses in on itself. You start out in a Zelda-esque level and you have to unlock movement, sound, scrolling, color, art style and much more via chests. At first it brought out the nostalgia and was endearing to see someone poke fun at the absurtiy that was the sheer volume of items you had to collect and find to progress in the Zelda franchise.
But when you have to unlock everything through chests like peoples, towns, even the creatures you have to fight, the joke gets old; quick. As soon as you finish collecting all the abilities and few treasures that you can collect with those newfound abilities (you collect stars that are useless and cards that can be used as a FF rip-0ff card game called Double Twin), you move to the overworld in the style of Final Fantasy. You unlock those monsters and you will trigger fight events in the overworld section and certain dungeons from that point on. Which gets annoying quick because you they happen often and I mean often. So much to the point that I can't accurately discribe the distance from the first level to the first town in pixels or time, but I can in fight events. About 7-16. And the distance between the two isn't large; the whole everworld is the size of an average FFVII dungeon.
Why did the developer do this? Simple; to balance out the time you play Zelda style and FF so it's somewhat even. To put it into perspective, There are Two towns, 3 main quest dungeons, 3 secret dungeons, 3 quest areas and one secret area. If you did strictly the main quest, the areas are all Zelda style and take a few minutes to complete, one dungeon, and the boss fight. these would take up maybe 20-30 minutes of total gameplay. The towns are FF type and you skirt through the first on in seconds maybe 5 minutes if you really explore it, you move to the dungeon ahead which takes up 5-10 minutes because of how many fights you trigger and  the only other town you skirt right through in about the same as the first town. So with dungeons and areas alone, maybe 20 minutes max you spend doing turn style based combat. If you tried to find all the collectables, you'd add on another 20-60 minutes for Zelda style combat based on if you have already unlocked the airship (which is owned by Cid, another FF rip-off). So you spend most of the game playing as a Link clone rather than you do as a FF clone, even though to travel to different levels, you have to travel through the overworld which is all FF combat. But there are so few enemy types and all but one uses melee and they spawn so often that you end up trying to run away. There is only one Diablo level (a main quest dungeon) but its another button masher that you can complete in 5 minutes or less.
The music and scenery have vary few variations. Added to the boring gameplay, this helps to further decrease any desire to continue playing.  The plot is just Hey im a Cloud clone and you're an Aerith clone. Oh noes

reviewText:
1.2 hours in: Enjoyed the quickly evolving graphics/playstyle as you run around. Hack and slash mechanics are fun, as are the turn based battles (makes me want to play some Final Fantasy games). I've gone through one dungeon and fought a boss. Wasn't difficult, more just figuring out the mechanics of the fight and doing the right thing at the right time. So far, enjoying the game and want to play more!

2 hours in: I've finished the story up to the last boss. Let's be honest here, not an amazing story. The time travelling section was more tedious than creative or tricky. I plan to collect all of the hidden items in the game, but I think that may wait as I just don't really feel like playing more at the moment. But I do want to 100% the game.

6 hours in (I admit some of that time was spent afk with the game open): Just got 100% completion on the game. Was definitely tricky to find some of the hidden stars/cards, but once you figure out where you need to go, you can usually find the ones you missed the first time around (hint: wall hugging is a good idea). Some of the end game areas were rather tricky with the time travelling mechanic, so that was nice. The final boss was actually quite perfect. Took me a few tries to understand how it worked, but once I did, I was able to down him quite easily.

Overall, I would say it's an enjoyable game. After the first hour, you've pretty much unlocked all of the visual and/or mechanic upgrades that you are going to get. That being said, I did enjoy playing through different game styles; it was definitely fun and brought back some great memories of other games. I don't think there is much replay-ability with this one.

I would say the game is worth at least half price. Definitely enjoyable, but gets a bit repetitive after the first hour when you are going back and hunting treasures. I think I physically played the game maybe four hours, so I would recommend, but only if it's on a sale.

reviewText:
I'm a bit perplexed as to why this game is rated as positively as it is. Still it's not a bad game in itself, but the flaws are very distracting.

An overview. This is a loveletter (I dig that phrase now) to a nostalgic RPG time. There's heavy Zelda and Final Fantasy (interestingly 7 almost exclusively, with the exception of the card game from 8)  and other generic JRPG. There's even a bit of ARPG in the Diablo vein, but mostly above all is Zelda. I saw a mention of pokemon, didn't see that at all.

Anyway, the game starts out as a 2d zelda (think zelda 1 and snes zelda) and hits a high point at around the time when you can move between a `modern' game and a `classic' game to solve a few puzzles.

Aside from that though, there isn't much content. There's a handful of enemy types, three weapons, and a lot of the worst part of jrpgs. Your character seems to walk around painfully slow, and random encounters are mind boggingly frequent, which makes them even more annoying because

1) There are no interesting rpg mechanics at all.
2) There any challenge that merits gaining money/experience from completing the battles.

There are a number of average points. The controls are passable. The music is above par, though repetitive, and the story is completely stock going with the tongue-in-cheek style of satire.

The high point may be the graphics, specifically in the 2d scape. This game is one of the weird ones in that it doesn't seem to recognize that I have video cards, and so renders through my cpu, which is just fantastic at making the frame rate suffer enormously in 3d mode, particularly the final boss fight, which not only is graphically blocky, low-rez, no-texture anyway, but is rendered at an eye bleeding 1 fps. Seriously, this stuff is N64 quality, and I can emulate that fine on a decade old laptop, so I have no idea what the deal is here. A trillion little polygons hidden where you're not looking.

I got this in a bundle, and did put the time in to finish it, but I can't recommend this as anything more than throwing away a quarter or two when you're particularly patient.

reviewText: Evoland could have been something great, and the first 30 minutes are lots of fun, but after that it just gets boring. There is no replayablility, and what is there isn't that interesting.  I'm disappointed that this great idea was not executed in a professional manner.

reviewText:
This game was refreshing.  Evoland made me realize that you don't need an extremely powerful computer to have fun with games.  It had my nostalgia levels through the roof.  I felt it was a different turn in gaming, if that makes any sense.

For a 3 - 6 hour game, I found it did an exceptional job of letting you look into the history of hack-and-slash games.  From LoZ to Diablo, it lets you experience those fond childhood memories again.

I am not denying its flaws however.  It was not by any means an enthralling story, but I think people expect too much from a 4 hour game.  For what you are picking it up for, I think it is money well spent.

This game is creative, there is nothing like it on the market.  I've never seen a game poke and prod at other games in such a cheeky manner, while still making it enjoyable.  Playing through the game twice (yes I have no life), I rode the nostalgia rollercoaster through to the end with a grin on my face throughout.

I wouldn't pay full price for it, but if it ever goes on sale I would highly recommend to everyone, young and old, to give it a try.

78/100

reviewText:
TL;DR: Don't spend money on this.  It's extremely grindy and not very well made.  You can also play the 2D portion of the game for free as a Flash-powered game in your browser.

The rest of the review:

Evoland was an interesting concept that originated from a Flash-powered browser game of the same title, but the execution of this remake was rather disappointing.

I was having fun with the constantly changing environment and controls and other features, but then the game slowed down.  I started having to grind my stats up to survive the random battle encounters.  I also had to grind loot to get a few of the achievements.  I wasn't seeing the constant changes any more.  I missed the fast pace of the 2D portion of the game and felt that the 3D portion of the game just wasn't as satisfying.  Eventually, I gave the game up without getting through its entire story due to lack of interest.

reviewText:
A formidable idea but a terrible realisation ( even for a 5 men team ).
I had, at first, a little smile on my face while playing this game because the idea wrapping it seemed great at first.
A game where you travel through gaming history while revisiting some of the most recognizable games of all time ( Zelda, Final Fantasy, Diablo ),
a game where the gameplay itself evolve during your walk through the adventure, a game where...

Wait, I already lied. The game stops innovating passed the first hour and starts to be redondant and to be constitute of random fights every 5 seconds;
and that's the whole problem surrounding this game. The synopsis and publicity makes you think they took the best of the games it was inspired of, but it's false...

They took the worse.

The +:
- The idea being original and meta.
- The graphics evolution, from black and white/2D/80's" graphics to pre-rendered backgrounds and 3D fights.
- Some jokes and allusions may be funny...

The -:
- But the majority of them are just cringe worthy and could've been written by a 12 years old.
- Talking about the writting
date: the story is absolutely.. I DON'T EVEN KNOW WHAT IT IS
recommended: BECAUSE IT'S NOT THERE!\n- You can basically buy two usable items ( potions and phoenix down )
hoursPlayed: a couple of swords and armors

votesTotal: I'm pretty sure my character should've died from blunt trauma considering the number of times he took a tree right in the face.. *SecondShotOfWhiskey*\n- Lack of innovation after the first hour. Lack of an envy to live too.\n- The random encounters. Every 5 seconds. A fight. Against the same 7 ennemies. Doing the same 2 actions. Earning the same amount of XP. The same amount of Glis ( Yes

reviewText: Evoland is a nice original game that takes you through the evolution of gaming, from side-scrolling adventure to 3D enhanced fighting, while still being it's own adventure game. It does have a lot of influences from mostly the Legend of Zelda series and the Final Fantasy series (and they're not hiding that fact), and it works for this game!\nIt is fairly short though, and if you're not bothering to find all the hidden stars and cards, you can get through this game in a couple hours time. But that doesn't take away the fun out of this game. It's a nice pick me up for inbetween those more serious games you like to play.

reviewText:
I thought this was going to be something fairly cool and in someways it is, but it was also very disappointing and frustrating. Now that said $2.5 is incredibly cheap for a game so perhaps I did get my money's worth after 5 hours of play.

The area that really upset me was the Diablo-like area in the middle of the game. (I don't know actually how near to the end this is.) I ended up stopping play after a couple hours of trying to fight against the lag and beat the boss. The battle of which would be hard even without lag. The lag was tied to specific areas in the game but unfortunately needing to be mobile meant crossing those areas eventually and it was a good likelihood you'd get slapped for 60-80% of your health before you could escape. This leads to a very lethal ending.

The game itself is somewhat funny in its send up of various Roleplaying" and Adventure gaming styles. I say that in quotes because my idea of RPGs doesn't include getting wrist strain from pounding on the keyboard. (By the way the game is played entirely on the keyboard with 0 mouse input
date:
though it seems to have capability to interface with a gamepad.)

The best parts were the transitions obtained from opening chests and the worst parts were the attempts to create a mini game that plays like a platformer with inadequate controls. I was initally attracted to the game after looking at its store page because of the image of various transitions in particular what looked like a full diabloesque inventory screen turns out to be a joke. Unfortunately the joke is on the player because it is entirely useless in the game.

I don't mind jokes in games (in fact humor makes a game so much better in my opinion.) However this game takes the joke a little too far by making it at your expense. Oh the items you pick up in the Diabloesque area do nothing whatsoever and may get you killed a few times trying to get them before you realize this? OK. Ha...ha? Also a part of me thought it was a really cool idea to go from a 2d Nintendo game to a fullblown modern game with full RPG elements but alas that was merely a false impression.

The last thing that makes me say "Don't buy this" is the fact that the devs seem entirely absent from the Steam forums now. The last response coming in April of 2013."

reviewText: The trailer makes this game seem much more inspiring than it in actuality is: Although the retro, evolving playstyle is unique and at first nostalgic, it's fairly clear that the developers did not have sufficient resources at their disposal to finish gradually updating the graphics to present-day, and as such, about halfway through the game, the evolution prompty stops. This is besides the fact that the progression is painfully general, at some points changing almost nothing and at others skipping whole years of the industry's steps - I'm sorry, but the change from 2d to 3d did not happen overnight, as this game seems to depict.\n\nI fancy myself as being able to appreciate games that go to lengths to make a statement, but beyond establishing it, this game does not really go any further. The game lacks a substantial or original plot, has a fairly limited interface, is laughably short, gets repetitive quickly, and has absolutely no replay value.

reviewText: A love letter to the types of games I played growing up, its a bit of a hybrid Final Fantasty/Ledgend of Zelda game. reviewText:
First of all, you have to understand that this is not a normal story-based game. The main purpose of this game is to give a history lesson into the evolution of gaming.

The gameplay is nothing special and becomes extremely repetitive, but this is the way older games used to be. From that perspective, you could say that the game is doing exactly what it set out to do, imitate older games.

There is some potential here. You could give this game to your kids to show them what the games we used to play were like. As they play through it, they will learn to appreciate every small detail.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
As a love letter to the games of past, this game manages to capture the exact feelings of what it was like playing them when growing up. Unfortunately, this also includes all the frustrations that come with it.

Sparse save points and a really awkward control scheme with no way of adjusting keybindings (the controller support is quite limited in customisation) leads to a lot of painful gameplay, and leaves you wondering if that was intended or not.

If you're looking for something in a similar vein to this, skip this one and try the sequel. They've learnt from people's frustrations with this.

3/10 This is a review from someone who completed the game
Let's do a simple pros and cons list

Pros
-The evolution of the game is pretty neat, start off as an 8-bit gameboy like game and end as high-def" 3D models. Kind of remoinds me of DLC quest in a way.
-The first half of the game is actually pretty fun

Cons
-The story is pretty boring.
-Because the game switches between three styles (Top-Down Action like Legend of Zelda
date: Turn Based RPG like Final Fantasy
recommended: and Hack and Slash like Diablo) the devs didn't refine the battle systems all that well. The Action and Hack and Slash are very similar
hoursPlayed: but don't play as well as there counterparts. The RPG system is so unfinished. Levels do not matter and there is no MP so you can just spam special attacks.\n-Every two steps there is a random encounter in the overworld\n-some of the puzzles in-game require you to walk back and forth

To sum it up

reviewText:
It seemed like an interesting idea, but it failed to execute on it so badly.

It says I've played like 7 minutes, but I've played a few hours, probably around 5 to get all the steam achievements, and the reason seems to be related to how their Linux support works.  When you get an achievement, it tells steam you're playing it, gives the achievement, and then disappears from telling steam you're playing it again.  There was no steam overlay either, and I do have it enabled, so idk there.  Also, right off the bat it told me to install google chrome for pepperflash, but that didn't work, so I had to do some messing around with their config file and dropping a pepperflash version from someone's on the forums in order to play.

So, other than dumb issues, the game is basically a poor implementation of Zelda with the overworld and some areas being turn-based combat.  The turn-based combat has a level up system for some reason, but it does literally nothing, and the combat is nothing other than using the guy to attack and the girl to heal anyway, there's no skill" to it at all.  There is one area that takes the poor implementation of Zelda
date: and adds an hp-bar rather than hearts
recommended: and then throws a bunch of mobs at you in a sort of Diablo-ish sorta way
hoursPlayed: but the the combat sucked with the Zelda-ish stuff anyway so if anything it just made how bad it was more apparent."

reviewText:
As a love letter to the games of past, this game manages to capture the exact feelings of what it was like playing them when growing up. Unfortunately, this also includes all the frustrations that come with it.

Sparse save points and a really awkward control scheme with no way of adjusting keybindings (the controller support is quite limited in customisation) leads to a lot of painful gameplay, and leaves you wondering if that was intended or not.

If you're looking for something in a similar vein to this, skip this one and try the sequel. They've learnt from people's frustrations with this.

reviewText:
I started playing this game giggling like a little school girl. This is such an amazing concept that I can't believe this is the first weve seen of it (to my knowledge). Which is why it pains me that this game just doesn't 'evolve'... hehe.... into what it could be.

The first 45 minutes-hour have a lot of promise as you unlock new technologies and cycle through game modes... but after that it trickles out new unlocks and doesn't really go anywhere. It turns into a 'Bah-bies first Zelda clone'. I have got to be frank.... I don't like Zelda (Early titles). The gameplay just didn't do anything for me. I much prefer the strategy of turn based combat. Speaking of....

There is 0 depth to this game. From the combat to the story. During turn based sections you have yourself and a girl character. The girl is the mage who only starts with heal and you a basic attack. Then, by about half way through the game she finally gets 1 magic attack that does the same damage as your sword attack and you get nothing. Thats it. Even on the Zelda side of things nothing evolves past the early Zelda titles. You get a sword, bombs, and arrows.

The story is throw away.

The humour seems to just consist of 'Epic Movie' type refrences. You are a lucky lucky person if you dont know what that means....

Nothing is really done with the concept of evolving through the generations. I would love to see a larger scaled game maybe by some tested devs who could take this concept and just go nuts. I freaking love this idea and I hope to see it around again. Kudos to the devs for thinking of it but I really wish you would hahve developed it more.

Oh, also the game is only 3 hours long. I just kind of gave up half way in because I can't play old school style Zelda without a controller and I just couldn't get controller support to work. : /

Update: I noticed a You-tuber I like had a full playthrough of this so I decided to watch the rest of it to see what I missed. I have to say Im happy I gave up when I did.

The game turns into a diablo like (using that phrase lightly) game after I quit. Again like with the rest of the game there is no depth to it. You pick up loot that doesnt even effect anything and you are still using the combat mechanics from zelda. You get gold drops but gold is useless and cant actually be used for anything.

The story is laughable. Its so crap. I can't imagine what the devs thought when they cobbled that mess together. Maybe it was the day before release and all the writers has hangovers so they got the janitor who played an rpg once like 20 years ago to finish the story for them.

You get a map finally during this section but nothing else happens. The boss fight here is just as lame and uninspiered as the rest.

Then you fight the final boss and finally get a second attack for the main hero which is on a 4 minute cooldown and is only used once. The boss is in 2 sections. You get beat for the first fight and your compainion dies *spoilers but who cares*. You get an airship to get to where the boss moved to because reasons, and fight in a zelda type boss fight. Then credits roll. Thats it.

I can't understand how they were able to think of such an awesome concept for the game but didnt have a single good idea other than that. I pray I see this idea take shape from devs who are actually talented.

reviewText: It's an interesting idea. almost a satire, or self-satire, really. It's worth noting, but honestly, it feels clunky and suffers mechanically. reviewText:
A brilliant RPG, half-parody, half-reverence to the old games of yore. You'll see plenty of nods to old games, some more blatent than others, but the ability to progress through the evolution of game mechanics and graphics really is an experiance not to be missed. Progression is fast, but there is enough to keep the explorer in you on your toes for secrets! This really should not be missed by anyone who owned a console prior to the 'Next-Gen' era. I highly recommend it!

[Update] This is, however, an indie title and it shows. There is little more story to this game than pure immitation, calling mostly from Final Fantasy 7, with somewhat janky real-time temple roaming. Keep on your toes for game-breaking bugs though, especially with the Airship, which you can land in places you cannot reach again, requiring you to restart the game from the beginning.

That said: the game is fun, the references are enjoyable, and the gameplay is varied. It's a little jank, but well worth the experiance.

reviewText: This game was an amazing concept, and the first hour or so was great.  However as you begin to open the game up into the 3D part it really begins to fall apart.  The game becomes very repetitive in a grind form that doesnt actually progress your character in any form, its just content filler.  The controls are slow and very unresponsive (From a 360 game pad atleast)\n\nIts like they started building the game with this amazing concept, then realized towards the end how short it was and tried to fill it up with grinds that dont actually have any progression to them.  I have marked this game as DO not recommend,  However thats not my stance entirely I dont recommend it either I am completely neutral if its on sale and your interested I wont say dont buy it.  But come into it with low expectations.

reviewText: The start of this game was amazing,  it was a fantastic concept, and had an amazing charm. reviewText:
Review: EVOLAND

Evoland is a great game however some times it gets annoying.
So i'm going to help you make upyour mind weither to buy it or not.

Good:
1.8-bit graphics eventully turning into 16 bit,32,64 etc.
2.As you advance thourgh the game you get more stuff makeing the game easier and better.
3.It is good for retro gamers (8-bit 16bit) and good for modern games (3D)
4.Good for people who like action adventure games
5.Good for people who like rpg turn based games
6.Has quite a for achievements for achievement hunters

Bad:
1. At the start of the game your a one shot kill for a while. (Does get better when you get to the 3D part as you have more health.
2.The save points are quite far from each other which can get annoying.
3.You dont want to play it that much (sadily i promised my self i would finish it which may take a while as i will have too take breaks a lot).
4.You go into it hyped for an amazing action adventure game however that is not what you get.

Here are some quotes from people with the game and from myslef.

reviewText: Evoland is an interesting game concept. Accumulating game features as you go via chests or other means is enjoyable for a while, but after it slows down and stops you're not left with much. In some areas there is a tedious and rudimentary Final Fantasy battle system which will always threaten you with random death if you're not careful. In others there's a decent Zelda style adventure full of tedious dungeons but with inventive puzzles (especially the later one's). It's not an overly long game, but I feel like I would have gotten the point of the game with about 30% less overworld travel and maybe getting bombs earlier. Completionists be warned, you'll want to keep very close track of where you need to come back to later, as there are things you need to come back to in the endgame to get in seemingly every area. Also, the Final Fantasy card game makes an appearance, and I'm even less inclined to play it here than I was in FF8.\n\nOverall it's hard not to recommend Evoland. I had fun playing it, but replay value isn't high. My completion percentage at the end of the game was 92.9% and I didn't feel compelled to go out and get the last 2 or 3 things I missed in random chests.

reviewText: EvoLand. I thought to myself when first seeing the games title that it was going to be possibly a very GOOD Adventure/ RPGish type of game. But i then found out when Playing that it wasn't all it was cut out to making itself. Literally the way the entire game goes is you start off an a Gameboy world and collect chests that can either enchance the graphics or add other features such as taller grass housing developments and more retro type music. The game controls for the keyboard and mouse IMO are a little bit off imo. Other than that though the game its self is just... Kinda boring nothing really blows your mind, No really amazing special effects and they only go to about the amount of FFVII's graphic style. Which also your companion for the game sucks I mean really sucks shes only good for healing dont EVER USE HER TO ATTACK you'll regret it. Literally if you like only 2 Hit Damage On a Monster go ahead keep doing it. The company even resorts to having an exact replica of a statue of BOWSER from Mario in the game. Um how did they sneak that in and Nintendo didnt notice it? Seriously Nintendo needs to know about this PRONTO! I honestly had more higher hopes for this game as it was suppose to take like a Zelda and FinalFantasy game instead though the very end of the game is gonna leave you thinking Wow I spent 3 almost 4 hours on a game and beat it with no problem". And thats it its very short
recommended: and just pretty bland. If you buy this game get it when its on sale at like $5 or lower. Otherwise if you see this for higher than $9 dont get it. It will leave a little bad taste in your mouth. 5/10"

reviewText:
I usually hate indie games because they're bad cash-ins without anything interesting and made without any real heart on the developer's end. They're shallow and incredibly not worth the bang for the buck.

This time, I found something not awful.

Honestly it's fun and interesting if short. A series of RPG tropes and technology through the years. Plenty of decent references but then there's all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ look @ me i'm a 90s kid guys do you remember the 90s please guys remember the 90s with me" moments with parts of the in-game text. Gameplay is based around what era of RPG you are in. There's an achievement every five steps

reviewText:
Wow.  This left me smiling and laughing throughout the entire game.  The premise is simple -- starting from simple right-only movement, and progress through RPG history (circa ~2000's).  There's so much overlapping and nuanced inclusion of so many RPG defining moments in this game that it left me thinking about those old RPG's as I played through this game.

Nostalgia is one hell of a drug; and this game oozes it.

For most RPG players, this game is a trigger mechanism to remember your favorite moments of RPG history, from many, many games.

If you've played through Final Fantasy, Zelda, Ultima, Dragon's Quest, Secret of Mana, Diablo... you must play this game.

If you haven't, you really need to play through all of those series to enjoy this game.

5/5
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I put off playing this game for quite a while, because, well, I guess I just didn't think it would be that good based on what I'd seen. But now, I cannot stress enough how wrong I was.

The game is fantastic. Sure it's gimmicky, but it felt like I really was playing every RPG from my past. And it didn't feel cheap, or lazy, the game mechanics were actually VERY impressive. Even knowing what the game was trying to do, I was still shocked at how well it analyzed and represented all the old games I played on various systems.. from NES to PS2. The only thing I disliked about the game is the $#@%ing card game you can play; so frustraiting. Other than that, maybe some better music? There's not much to dislike.

Do not take it lightly when I say this game may actually steal the spot of my #1 indie PC game from Bastion. And for $10, it's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ steal. Buy it, you don't know what you're missing.

reviewText: Evoland explores the evolution of the Zelda and Final Fantasy games. The game starts out in Gameboy monochromatic and continues to 8-bit, 16-bit, PSX styled blocky 3D, and finally hi def 3D. The dungeons are explored in the same fashion of the old school Zelda games while the overworld aspect has random battles and leveling up. The entire game is filled with parodies pertaining to not only the genres but tropes in Zelda and Final Fantasy specificially. A great game that will only take 3-4 hours but will completely be worth it!

reviewText:
This game is a bit hard to describe (watch the trailer), but it's rather enjoyable.
The first half of the game is like a stroll through RPG gaming history, and it let's you appreciate every major gaming innovation of the past 25 years. The last half of the game is a simple little story filled with clever writing and amusing references to games past.

It's short, it has variety, you learn a bit, and some parts will make you laugh.

reviewText: This is a really interesting game that tells a story about the clichés of gaming. It's like an RPG, but instead of upgrading your character, you upgrade the game itself. For instance, you might unlock 256 bit color" as opposed to 16 bit or "free roaming" as opposed to moving along a grid. Some areas even allow you to cycle from modern graphics and mechanics to older ones
date: allowing you to bypass some limitations introduced in more modern games. This makes for a very interesting and enjoyable way to solve puzzles.\n\nYou progressively move from a sidescroller to a game like Torchlight or Diablo
recommended: without lingering on one particular thing; except for random-encounters. Random-encounters appear literally every few seconds in specific portions (mainly fast-travel) of the game-- and it's terribly boring. The whole point of the game is to continure moving from one thing to another
hoursPlayed: except for some odd reason they decided to keep those through the entire game. Now
voteText: sometimes they're fun
helpfulPercent: but the main character only has one attack for the better part of the game. This really discourages exploration-- and it takes a lot of time
votesHelpful: mainly because you are granted a mini-map very late in the game. (It's sometimes hard to find where you need to go with random-encounters interrupting you every few seconds.)\n\nThat aside
votesTotal: it's honestly a refreshing experience to see all the generations of gaming packed into one 3.5 hour game. The gameplay mimics the gameplay of the generation you are currently dwelling in
votesFunny: and it does it very well. It seems like a lot of time was put into Evoland
commentsCount: everything was polished well to fit with the various themes.\n\nI think this game is worth it at full price for some people
column16: but also would not be enjoyed by others. I certainly enjoyed it
column17: and if anything I've said sounds interesting
column18: I recommend that you give it a try."

reviewText:
If you are a child of the 80s and 90s and need a nostalgia trip stop reading now and buy this game.

Everyone else? The gameplay is short. It has no replayability. It is not innovative except for the fact that it tells the story of the history of gaming and shows how the technology of gaming has progressed over the decades. So the question is, does it sound worth it to you?

I recommend this game to anyone that wants to see the story of how we went from the years after the collapse in 1983 upt and (and including) Diablo 3. How the technology has progressed. And experience some of the type of gameplay that you saw in Zelda and Final Fantasy titles. But purely as a game? No, probably not worth it.

reviewText:
A wonderfully inventive game, Evoland features a mixture of game play between the Legend of Zelda series and the Final Fantasy series. You start out with only black and white, 2 dimensional game play. You unlock colors, graphics, 3 dimensional gameplay, sound and sound quality, gameplay features and basically everything to do with a game by finding the different and many chest found throughout the game.

It also features (true to the Final Fantasy spirit), a mini card game within the game. You can find or buy cards to play it. A fun plot (once you unlock the storyline as you do everything else including basic movement), it keeps you entertained for hours. You also unlock the ability of save points found scattered throughout the land, health (which when in Zelda mode shows as hearts in the upper right hand side of the screen). When in Final Fantasy open world exploration mode with radom encounters, battles play out as made famous by the Final Fantasy series up to Final Fantasy IX.

More unlocks and fun than you can imagine, the gameplay is highly addictive and keeps you smiling. Dungeons also unfold where you must move blocks onto pressure pads to open gates or put you in trap rooms where you must defeat all the monsters within to escape, and mazes unfold as well. I could not for the price range recommend many games as highly as this one for absolutely any gamers collection. On a scale of 1 to 10, 1 being horrible and 10 being the most awesome game of all time, this one would rank as a solid 9. Well worth the investment.

reviewText:
Summary: A game you'll likely play once, but enjoy every nostalgic minute of the roughly 3 hour storyline.

Hours of fun: 3 hours
Suggested Retail Value: $5
Graphics: 6/10
Voice-acting: 6/10
Music/SFX: 6/10
Uniqueness: 6/10
First Play-through Experience: 7/10
Replay Value: 5/10

Evoland is a fun game for anyone who has a love for old-school RPGs, an interest in how RPGs have changed over the last couple of decades, or just want to experience an adventure that spans several generations of RPG all in one sitting. If that's true of you then I doubt you'll regret buying it, and you can probably expect to want to talk to others about it. I doubt anyone would regret paying $5 or less for this, though there may be a small number of gamers who would feel the story was too short to justify spending more. It's likely to wake the little kid in you, and will probably make you want to play through your library of classics"
date: but I doubt you'll want to play through the game a second time just to find all the "Hidden Stars". But maybe that's just because I dislike collection quests
recommended: and so completely ignored that aspect of the game (which you can easily do!)."

reviewText:
If you are a child of the 80s and 90s and need a nostalgia trip stop reading now and buy this game.

Everyone else? The gameplay is short. It has no replayability. It is not innovative except for the fact that it tells the story of the history of gaming and shows how the technology of gaming has progressed over the decades. So the question is, does it sound worth it to you?

I recommend this game to anyone that wants to see the story of how we went from the years after the collapse in 1983 upt and (and including) Diablo 3. How the technology has progressed. And experience some of the type of gameplay that you saw in Zelda and Final Fantasy titles. But purely as a game? No, probably not worth it.

reviewText: I both liked and hated Evoland. The controller didn't want to work. I found a fix" online that worked for me until I restarted my computer. From that point forward the fix would no longer work for me and I had to play the second half of the game with the keyboard instead. The controls with the controller were wonky and craptastic
date:
when I played with the keyboard they actually turned out to be a lot better. I think that kind of sucks as this feels like the kind of game you want to play with a controller.

Combat. The only time combat seemed to work well was in the turn based sequences. Every other form of combat in the game was so clunky that I got hit a lot when I really should not have. This caused a lot of annoyance.

I ran into a few bugs
recommended: one of which caused me to have to return to the menu and restart from the last save point due to my having gotten myself somewhere that the developer didn't intend by thinking I was completing part of one of their puzzles. I really feel like the QC process on this game must have been terrible.\n\nBasically
hoursPlayed: I enjoyed the idea of the game. I thought the actual gimmick of the game - unlocking various new technological advances in video games over time - was pretty cool. There is a section where you alternate between two different techs so as to complete a puzzle - I thought that section was great but it is also the place where I managed to break the game as mentioned above.\n\nSince steam goes with a rating of recommend or not recommend
voteText: I am choosing not to recommend this game due to the fact that the developers didn't bother to work out the kinks and left me with a frustrating experience.\n\nFor the record
helpfulPercent: I played the entire game all the way through. I liked it enough to finish

reviewText:
This is by no contest the last game I would ever recommend anyone to buy at any price, and even to play. I would sooner give them an old playstation underground cd than point them this way.

Why? because for the most part, this game is just a demo, scattered caves and small concept dungeons that sell and only tease nostalgia. Even in older demos and games I was more willing and enjoyed grinding exponentially more than in this game.

It is a great concept, and pulls from a great resource of games. Running back and forth through times and generations is something that would attract anyone who wanted more from a new generation and was willing to go back to get a good story, I mean, that's what is usually the grounds for tossing graphics out of the window. But this game misses it on so many levels. It looks good, and goes through the graphical changes in game and even musical changes. But the gameplay plateaus extremely too early. Even before you've gotten 3d you can call it over.

The biggest flaw in this game is that, it's not necessarily bad, but if you even begin to explain what this game tries to be or what it should be, it sets everyone up to be disappointed, and the only place it should belong in is a class where they skim over concepts that have so much more to them to the point where even robot chicken gives you more character depth. I really don't like games that will literally make you want to stop playing it to go back and enjoy the referenced games rather than choose this one. And it does very well to keep you from enjoying it.

Also, a really bad part is that this game exists at all, so someone who could have done it better is probably going to have to try a completely different approach to addressing older games and experiences or avoid it altogether. Where in fact the approach itself is spot on, the exchange between lands is also solid, the references are blatant enough to see, but there isn't enough game to bother with it and not just sit through a youtube walk through and tell yourself what a good reminder it is of how far things have come. but only those who know already will understand how far it has come in a gameplay sense.

Pass this game. You can do a whole lot more for less. Maybe they will make a sequel that is better and displays more of the depth in those games to the point where it is actually a game. Until then, It's just a project that used all the best supplies and still failed. Which to me is the worst kind of failure.

reviewText: At no point was there anything resembling proper difficulty. It was either mind-numbingly easy or painfully tedious. The plot was nothing but a collection of cliches, without a single attempt to actually connect the player to what was happening. It's like if Seltzer and Friedberg designed a videogame, except that they'd at least try to make things funny (and fail miserably). This just dragged on and on and on until I just wanted to get 100% completion so I could uninstall the game completely.\n\nI honestly do not understand why anybody would think that this was worth charging money for. I've played self-referential games with better jokes, better gameplay and actual plots, and they were free.

reviewText:
As others have said, this is NOT a game.  It's just an interactive story that forces you to relive a bunch of game-mechanics tropes that may or may not have been fun in the first place -- and certainly aren't all that interesting now.

You progress through the stages with minimal effort or thought, watching each stage of gaming history unfold, failing to laugh at the jokes that arenl't terribly funny, and wishing Evoland had half the plot of any one of the games referenced by it.

But sadly, no.  No game, minimal story, maximal boredom.  I've gotten far more nostalgia out of a conversation with friends than from this waste of money.

reviewText:
Evoland is a great journey through the evolution of game history.
Its graphic style changes with the progress from a retro pixel look to 3D graphics.
Its filled with little references to other games like The Legend of Zelda & Final Fantasy (VII).
The main concerne about this game is the little play time it's got. In about 4 hours you can play it till end, and afterwards there aren't many thing you can do anymore, except if you like to hunt the steam achievements ;)
Overall a game with a very cool idea which was nice implemented into the game, but I'ld recommend you to wait till it's on sale the next time, because of the short fun factor..

The sequel is already out, and I'm looking forward to play it! :)

7/10

reviewText:
[Overall rating 2/5]

I must begin with saying that when I first heard about this game I couldn't wait to playit, but when I finally found out my bf bought it in a bundle, the only reason I actually played for the full 4 hours was because I spent 1 of them searching for more interesting content I were convinced must be there somewhere because of the good reviews. I didn't find it.

The beginning is fun and it felt accomplishing earning new dimensions and mecanics, until you get the 3D graphics, after this point the gameplay grows more teadious for every new stage and the controls are imprecise. This was for me very frustrating. I continued playing only because I waited for it to be as fun as in the beginning  (the first 20 min) again.

I found the the Final Fantasy battles charming and fun at first, but also this got old quickly because of the low variation of attacks, enemies and characters, and when you finally gain new attacks the character choise immideatly shrinks, and guess what more? You no longer have any relevant battles in this style of gaming to use them in. Not. Worth. It.

The boss battles are unimaginative and boring, ESCPECIALLY the last one which I completed first after a hiatous of a few weeks because it was so teadious and the controls so bad that I couldn't bring myself to finish it. When I finally did, it was only because I wanted to give a fair review.

Except for the first, Zelda-esque part of the game, the absolutly only part I enjoyed was the in game card game, which I also spent about 20 min with. If that was released as a android game I probably would buy it. Would I now buy Evoland at full price? No. As a homage or satire, it's perfectly fine, but maybe at the price of a few euro.

reviewText:
After spending hours trying to find the upgrade that made the gameplay fun and interesting, and combing through a walkthrough, I was dismayed to learn no such upgrade exists.

I gave this game way too many opportunities to redeem itself, and it never did. I saw it in the store, and it looked nice. A friend got it and played it. Told me it wasn't worth my money. So that wouls have been the end of it, but I think I ended up with a copy froma  Humble Bundle or something. It sat in my library for about a year, until, bored one day, I fired it up.

It starts out in the standard manner for this sort of game - you start with one direction of movement, then unlock the others. Cheesy, but the earliest games were reestricted to lateral movement and the like, so I was game. Up until you pick up the transition from grayscale to 16 colors. The grayscale setup was a bit of a stretch, since graphics never really worked that way for early games (not counting  handhelds), but I was being lenient. 16 color made it clear that the designers had never really looked at the graphics for anyhting earlier than Playstation era. Even if the system could handle so many colors on a single sprite, it means the main character permanently occupies half the available pallette of the world. (Fun fact: Mega Man had to be composed of two sprites to support his whopping total of 5 colors).

Clearly, the developers were aware of how much they messed up 16 colors, because they jumped to 256 colors almost immediately. As noted above, though, they never did the same for the gameplay. In fact, they actively made the gameplay worse than the old games they claim to emulate - as part of a cheap gimmick, you get an upgrade that unbinds you from the grid. While that should be a good thing, it means you're out of alignment with enemies more often than not. And 95% of the game still uses a grid, so you're not getting much benefit from it. Up to and including gaps between trees like the cute barrier they put in place for you to bypass - nearly indistinguishable from the normal grid barriers, and exceedingly rare.

Problems like this pop up so often that it becomes clear that the immediate jump from 16 colors to 256 wasn't any sort of self-awareness; they want the game to be pretty" as fast as possible. They take way too long to add a health bar to progress beyong 1 hit = death. They add a "Loading" screen that costs 5000 GP to get rid of - from random fights that drop 100-200 GP each (not that there's much worthwhile to spend your money on
date: but it's still a stupid aproach).\n\nThings start to get some hope when they drop you into a Diablo-style section
recommended: but that's msotly padding and an excuse for cheap jokes - back to the status quo after that. With one exception - you get a combo chain ability (because we all know that Diablo invented the combo chain).\n\nAll in all
hoursPlayed: it starts off with some promise
voteText: but the hope for it to get better gradually fades. On top of that
helpfulPercent: 2/3 of the way through the game
votesHelpful: you've unlocked pretty much eveything
votesFunny: it may as well be called "Spinal Clam SE: Heaven". Except that still gives too much credit to the story writing."

reviewText: Product received for free\n\nI played this game on a whim while looking through my friends games in the family share. This game brought back so many fond memories of playing Diablo, Final Fantasy VII-IX, and even Shining force. If you grew up with older games then you owe it to yourself to give this game a try, if not then see what you missed. The plot of the game was 90% parodies of older games but you shouldn't come to this game looking for plot, that's not what this game is about, it's about nostalgia and it nails its goal. I also loved all the snarky jokes they threw in during each evolution. I fully plan to buy Evoland II and I hope they make a III. Enjoy a slice of history (and if you don't want Final Fantasy VII ruined play it first, though at this point who hasn't played it or had it ruined?)

reviewText:
Fun, creative game with some serious difficulty curves
Evoland is a creative game that does face a few problems. I loved the idea, starting from 8-bit, and transitioning all the way into 3D graphics. It is not limited to the graphics, and evolves as it goes along, fitting the evolutions into the story. It throws in turn-based battles, save points, and nearly any general advancement along the way. However, while all of this is cool, it has a few problems.

It's too short; it only has about four hours of gameplay not counting:

The difficulty curves. Some areas are waaay too hard, and can seriously hinder progress.

Leveling up only counts toward turn based battles. The hard areas are a great example of this. Plus, you don't level up in these areas.

Many evolutions don't stay around for very long, or aren't used very much.
Overall: 7/10, still recommended to try

reviewText:
Evoland was a fun little diversion from all of the mainstream games that I've been playing lately. It provided me with some fond memories of old school games, though it came with a few flaws. Definitely worth your time, but don't expect to fill your weekend with just this game.

Good:The action turn-based combat system was very solid.
There was plenty of collectables that were hidden decently well.
The story did not drag on as some older adventure/RPG games tend to do.
The later half of the game looks absolutely amazing.
There was a fun little card based minigame that directly tied into the collectables.
The Diablo inspired section was very fun.
Seeing the game portrayed in all the different art styles was very fun.
Bad:The Zelda inspired combat sections have wildly fluxuating difficulty.
The adventure segments lacked any real puzzles.
The party size was very limited compared to most RPGs.
The game felt a little short, especially for an adventure/RPG game. I beat it in approximately five hours and while I didn't obtain all collectables, I still managed to beat the game with 90% completion.
The card minigame's harder difficulties relied a little too heavily on RNG rather than strategy. Despite this, I still managed to beat all dificulties without collecting all the cards.
The end of the game didn't really have a solid payoff, relying more on presumed emotional ties rather than a solid conclusion.

reviewText:
Evoland is a very fun game in both concept and execution. Through out the game you will be taken on a journey through the evolution of games over the years.
Evoland = Evolution Land".

The game starts out in a retro gameplay style similar to the original "Legend Of Zelda"
date: and your hero is a young boy named Clink which is rather close to Link our favorite Hyrule hero.\n\nThrough the game you will see two main combat styles including: an over world random encounter much like "Final Fantasy" and dungeon crawling similar to "Legend of Zelda
recommended: Diablo"\n\nLike most games it is dangerous to go alone so early on in the story you will have a heroine join your party. You also receive new items through the game that help you to solve some basic puzzles. Also if saving the world starts being a little too much to handle
hoursPlayed:
take it easy and play yourself a game of double down! Evolands very own TCG game.


It is up to you
voteText: save the world of Evoland from the forth coming shadow set to destroy your home. Weather you wish to complete the main story clocking in at around 3-5 hours or 100% completion including (Collecting Stars & Double Down Cards) this game has a lot to offer and will leave a positive impression on you. I look very forward to playing Evoland 2 very soon and if you would like to see the game in action check out my full Youtube playthrough/walkthrough in the link below.\n\nEvoland Playthrough/Walkthrough Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLN5UUB4p8yP7TsKZEh7AUIa78_DTJuZwLL"

reviewText: Evoland is a journey through the first few generations of video games. Starting with simple black and white 8-bit graphics that resemble the earliest GameBoys, it slowly evolves into Nintendo 64 era features. Each time the player opens one of many treasure chests scattered across the worlds, new graphical, musical, or sound effects are unlocked." In this way
date: the game slowly progresses through the history of action/adventure video games.\n\nObviously inspired by classics like The Legend of Zelda

reviewText:
When i first saw a picture of Evoland in Steam Store i was immediatly closing it cause it shows an 8bit green-grey, C64 style. Nothing against C64, i still have one, but i wont see that in 2013.

Then i saw a little review accidently where i saw 3D grahics in it. My interest was awakened.

Evoland is a time-travel between the grapic engines from C64 style to today. But the biggest reference of it is Final Fantasy VII.

As mentioned you start with 8bit graphic and have to learn how to walk left and right, some minutes later you will unlock sounds and shortly thereafter COLOR!!! Well, the time from C64 to your first 3D effect is not very long, your first 3D HD graphics will come after 1 hour already.

The whole game took me only ~4 hours. It was good invested 4 hours for me, for the price we could fight. 10€ (Sep2013) is ok but 5€ would be more fair for that playlength.

The story is kinda funny, not only cause of that much references. 7/10

reviewText:
Pretty decent game if you've grown up with JRPGs as a kid. With particularly heavy homages to Final Fantasies 6-9. Even some Diablo, since it's technically an RPG?

You'll move from Zelda like combat, to turn-based ala classic FF. And I don't want to spoil anything too heavily, but FF7 fans will notice alot of shout-outs, and one scene especially should hit pretty close to home.


Only get it on sale though, IMO. And at $2.50 or less. Even at 50% off ($5), it wouldn't be worth it. I completed this game in 6 hours, and that's with all achievements cleared. If you were to do a regular playthrough I'd expect you to clock in 3-4 hours max before finishing.

reviewText:
A Zelda and Final Fantasy fan love letter.

This title is pretty short and full of RPG in-jokes, and that's part of its charm of course, but the real accomplishment here is the standout blend of nearly every genre defining aspect of retro (and in some ways even modern) RPGs.

Evoland starts in a very gameboy-like monochrome pixelated setting, and you start by unlocking the arrow keys for movement, and then the scrolling screens so you can move to different areas, and then enemies, and then a weapon to fight said enemies. Get a little further still and you'll unlock a color display! Wow color!

The unlockable everything aspect sort of reminded me of Half Minute Hero, though thankfully Evoland doesn't have that title's frantic time is running out constantly hurry hurry hurry!" methodology killing its fun factor.

It's neat to look back on the progression and see how things evolve as you play
date: and it's a fairly good reminder really to the way games of old have matured over the decades.\n\nI'd say the two plain-as-day obvious biggest influences on Evoland are the early Zelda titles
hoursPlayed: Final Fantasy 7. However there are a number of other small references here and there to others as well: Secret of Mana
voteText: Final Fantasy 4 and 6
helpfulPercent: Final Fantasy 8 just to name a few that I was easily able to recognize.\n\nThe story
votesHelpful: well there hardly is one
votesFunny: see Zelda/FF7 for the majority of parallels
commentsCount:
sometimes downright ripoffs honestly. Still the concept remains interesting throughout the relatively short campaign (it took me about 8 hours for 100% completion).

The fact that you don't have to sink 100+ hours into it is actually welcome. It gets the point across and manages to be enjoyable without requiring a month's worth of your spare time.

If you are a fan of older RPGs and indie titles you'll definitely find something to like here. Just having multiple battle systems and graphical presentations in a single game and having it work well together is reason enough to give it a try. Not to mention the trip down memory lane."

reviewText: It's important to realise when playing this game that it isn't meant to be a true RPG - it's meant to be a pisstake of the RPG genre, wherein you have to unlock everything, right down to moving, saving and battling, and it does that absolutely brilliantly. I would reccomend this game to anyone who liked the old RPGs like Final Fantasy and the like - I for one found myself chuckling heartily at the little references here and there. A brilliant little stab at the RPG genre, Evoland is so deliberately generic that it's hilarious, and any retro game fan should pick it up for its nostalgic and its comedic value.

reviewText:
It's a really great concept. It's awesome to start the game in black and white and slowly unlock all the upgrades that came and went in RPGs. For the most part, it also has a great sense of humor. You'll LOL as you see it implement loading screens when it goes 3D and enjoy the many references to classics like Final Fantasy, Zelda and Dragon Quest. The Zelda segments, however, drag on WAY to long, if you ask me. With very few puzzles or deep mechanics, this game feels a good hour or two too long. Most dungeons are simply a walk and press attack romp and the turn based battles require no strategy at all. I'd wait till this puppy was on sale if I were you, but if you enjoyed the 8-bit and 16-bit RPG era as much as I did, you'll be glad you played this.

PROS:
Awesome Concept
Nostalgia Overload

Cons:
Too Much Filler
Zero Replay Value

reviewText: Playing and slowly evolving through gaming technology is a cool concept, however Evoland executes it very poorly. reviewText:
Evoland is a great example of a game that has a great concept, doesn’t know what to do with it, and then fumbles the ball at the one-yard line.

The first hour or so of Evoland is fantastic – it assaults you with nostalgia as you unlock upgrades to the game at a fast clip. Once you clear the first town, however, the flaws of the game become suffocating, and even though the game is only about three hours long, it felt like it should have only lasted for half of that.

For one thing, the randomized battles add a horrible amount of teeth-grinding fluff to the game – they appear early, and never fade away. The game’s Steam page promises fully real-time battles by the time you’ve upgraded Evoland enough, but in reality the active combat zones are few and far between. Enemy variety is very limited, and I would always try to busy myself with something else as I hammered on the “A” button during battles. There’s almost no fear of death, as your character is capable of healing and there is NO mana bar to limit the ability to do so. Enemy scaling is frustrating as well, as your character is capable of dealing damage that always seems to be about one point short of the mob’s maximum life bar, requiring multiple hits on multiple mobs for arbitrary EXP that really doesn’t seem to boost your stats in any measurable way. It’s dull and pointless.

Furthermore, the game begins to rely far too much on RPG tropes. Sure, that’s the main hook of the game, but I started to become annoyed when the main character, “Clink,” used a buster sword to fight the main villain, “Zephyros” (and guess what happened to the female protagonist, “Caris”). When I thought the story was going to deliver something at least somewhat original, or put a twist on a trope, I instead found myself wandering a field to hunt a “choboko.”

Speaking of the tropes, they don’t fully evolve the game, as I was expecting. If you get near the end of the game, after you’ve unlocked full 3D models and HD backgrounds, and you travel back to the starting village, the game automatically reverts back to SNES-era sprites. Backtracking actually becomes somewhat of an inconvenience.

In all, Evoland feels like an overpriced student game that managed to do a good job up front, when it really has no real legs to stand on. Not recommended – just watch the GiantBomb Quick Look and call it good.

reviewText:
Evoland takes a fantastic concept, the evolution of the action RPG, and plays it out with mixed results. The game begins in very simplistic 2D, but soon begins to play very similarly to the original top-down Legend of Zelda games (think Link's Awakening). After more time, the game progresses into full-blown 3D, more akin to PS1/PS2 Final Fantasy games, and even further onward to open exploration, like Diablo. There's all sorts of collectibles and monster encounters as you'd come to expect, and the package is hilarious and represents its source material very well.

However, the game isn't without its faults. The transition to 2D to 3D is somewhat rough, and the game starts to lose a bit of polish there. Also, at all points in the game, hit detection can act oddly, leading to your character taking hits due to some wonky hitboxes, or in some cases, pushing your character through walls in a dungeon, leading you unable to continue without restarting. These problems are obviously very annoying, and make the experience worse overall.

Would I recommend the game, given the balance of positives (nostalgic value, good design) and negatives (bad hit detection, suspect 3D game mode execution)? Yeah, but not at full price. The game is great for what it is, but it's short (the game takes 2-3 hours, maybe 4 if you are trying to collect everything), and the bugs can be very frustrating. Therefore, if you're interested in things like Zelda and Final Fantasy, be sure to give Evoland a look - if you can catch it for a large discount in a sale.

reviewText: I was hesitant of buying Evoland for the negative reviews it got, but I'm so glad I did!\n\nThis game is like watching a fast-forward replay of happy memories from my childhood & teenage years. Wouldn't recommend Evoland for anyone who hasn't played old RPGs because most of the game's enjoyment relies on knowing & cherishing them, but RPG veterans will get a real kick out of it.

reviewText:
I actually really like Evoland.
It's not a perfect game, and it's not for everyone.
What I like most about this game is that it parodies old RPGs and adventure games such as Zelda and FF6/7. Evoland does what I like best. It's not afraid to be itself. It makes fun of classics like FF7, and isn't afraid to do so, while also showing apreciation to it.
The gameplay is basically zelda and FF combined, but simplified.
The only real shortcomings of this game are the fact that it only lasts about 3-5 hours (about 10 for 100%), and that it has low replay value.
Overally, I really like Evoland, and for its very cheap price of 10 dollars, it's worth a buy.

reviewText:
This is a fun trip down memory lane.

Now, my paytime is far higher than what Steam is reporting.  There is some sort of bug where it only counts time on the start screen for some reason.  I'd say I've loged about 3 or 4 hours.

Combining Legend of Zelda with Final Fantasy and even some Diablo - this retro-ish RPG / Action RPG is really like several games in one.  Or at least, several tastes of games in one - as the entire game itself is not very long.

Starting from a Game Boy - esqe 4-color pixel graphic style game and moving up to Playstation 1 era 3D graphics, the game evolves (hence the name) and morphs in front of you, changing not just the look and feel of the game, but the game mechanics as well.

There are a lot of references in this game.  If you enjoy games like Saturday Morning RPG, Dragon Fantasy, or Retro City Rampage - then you will enoy this game.  If you want to be reminded of some of the best RPGs in the last 30 years - then you should give this a shot....  Just don't expect to replicate the entire experience, just get a brief taste - just enough to remind you of those games of old.

Despite its short length (I haven't finished it yet, but I've read that it can be finished is just a few hours) there is quite a bit of grinding.  Not really grinding to level up, mind you.  Just grinding because the random encounter rate on the overworld screen is so high that it actually discourages any time of exploration.  And the rewards from leveling up are so few, that grinding is completely pointless.

I mentioned it is like playing several different games at once.  One of the main complaints that I have is that these various game-styles are largely unrelated in practice.  If you level up and get more life / hit points in the Final Fantasy style turn-based fighting - it does not affect the number of hearts you have in the Zelda-like areas.

I've heard a number of people talk about wasted potential and missed opportunities in this game, and I believe there is some truth in that -- but the game is well worth playing, and I for one seriously hope that those missed opportunities will be fulfilled in some future Evoland 2.  And, if that game comes out - I will certainly be playing.

6.5 out of 10.  Better than average, good - but not great.

reviewText:
EvoLand is an RPG type game based off of The Legend Of Zelda, Final Fantasy and others, and I think it is a very wonderful game to play and pick up if you are looking for a short game. The total time it took me to play through the story once was about 2 hours, so the story isn't that long, but the environment is wonderfl along with the music and such.

It evolves from the basic gamestyle into present day gaming styles, but it has a few draw backs. For example what they took from Final Fantasy, the random encounters.....Oh boy I swear that these were so annoying and after awhile I just wanted to get to wear I was going rather then taking 10 steps and oh look another battle" FannnnnnTastic...-_- This become especially annoying when I was trying to 100% the game.

Other then that I think that the game is definitely worth the $10 price tag and if you have time to play a short game I would give it a go if I were you.

Numerical rating value would be: 8.5/10"

reviewText:
First off - I love this game. It's a ton of fun as long as you see it as an exposition of game style and not as a game itself. It's like playing through a documentary about the game industrys evolution. The game itself is somewhat simplistic, but you do get a chuckle out of it every few minutes and the bosses are tricky enough to keep your attention, but I had two major problems with it.

1. OMG random encounters. Every frickin' second. I understand that you probably want to level the character faster, but after a while I'm just hitting the a button repeatedly while I watch a movie on my other screen and not even paying attention anymore because it just becomes so boring. Once you get the ship it's kind of fixed, but the ship can't go everywhere - like to the starting map etc. If you want me to level faster give me more xp per kill - don't throw more fights at me. If you want me to focus on levelling before the boss, then tell me this and I will go do it - don't force it down my throat. Besides, my levels don't even count when I get to the final boss (I don't think so anyway).

2. The final boss fight. I just unlocked a new type of health bar, why am I back to hearts? No bueno. I understand you want to make this fight difficult, themost difficult in the game even, but do it by being clever, not by making me think you suck at storyboarding.

3. I know I said two problems but this is less a problem more a request. Make it longer! :) I love this game - I want to keep playing! There are so many more engines I could be unlocking! Quake, Source, or Unreal - I would love to play this as a true 3d rpg! Keep going please! :)

Those are my two (three) cents. Keep up the good work - if development people even read this lol

reviewText:
This game wears out its welcome after the first fifteen minutes. It quickly jumps through the early eras of gaming, which was the only reason I bought the game, and then devolves into an insipid mishmash of poorly executed gameplay.

To break it down, the game begins with a Zelda-stlye top down action game, which, while competently executed, lacks the aesthetic beauty, creativity, or excellent design which define excellent games like Link to the Past or Minish Cap. The visuals are uninspired, and the enemy design is limited to very few, extremely repetitive octorock clones and bats. There are one or two interesting boss fights, but it remains dull and uninteresting.

After this you are hurled into a truly horrifically designed Final Fantasy clone. Lacking a mana system, it is utterly dull and a chore to grind through. Outdated principals like random encounters and a totally pointless item system makes this truly digusting. To make it worse, this takes up the majority of the games 5 or 6 hour lifespan, and the endgame is almost nothing but it.

There are a few bright spots. Sort of clever Easter Eggs are hidden in a few spots, and the Diablo style level is both challenging and a scathing mockery of the goofy loot system in such games. Overall, however, the game is disappointing, uninspired, slapdash, and dull. There is no way in hell this thing is worth 10 dollars or your time. Heartily not recommended.

reviewText:
Where do I start with reviewing this game.. Evoland; The game that must had been inspired by Final Fantasy cause Choboko's are pretty similar to Chokobo's don't you think? Don't let that deter you though as the game is actually quite charming, and addictive. When I picked up the game I was almost immediately invested in the progress of the game as you literally play to continue evolving the environment you explore. I've never played Final Fantasy, but If it's turn based combat system is anything like Evoland (Call it a hunch, but I'm pretty certain it's a carbon copy) It's very fun, and refreshing from most A-List games I've been playing lately. The only con I truly have with this game is the pain of back tracking to find the one star, and double twin card to get two of my last three achievements before 100% the game.

In conclusion if you can find this game for anywhere between $1.00 - $3.00; I would highly recommend you give it a shot!
6.5/10

reviewText:
I found Evoland a fun game to play. The concept of making the “evolution” of video games an essential part of the game itself was well implemented, and I really liked the allusions to well known classics like Final Fantasy or Legend of Zelda. Although the battle system stays on a basic level, the boss fights are mostly a bit more of a challenge.

Though my impression was definitely positive, I would recommend Evoland rather to people who can revel in this homage to the RPGs of “good old days”.

reviewText: So late on this review, well I purchased this game the day that it came out or the day after not sure. Anyways it looked fun and for ten dollars, to me it looked like it was worth. So I gave it a shot, and to cut the review short to me the game is a four out of five. The different forms of combat are nice, but none of them are to extensive, which makes sense but a couple of other options would have been nice. The 3d to 2d gave an interesting puzzle or two I feel like the developers could have worked this a little more, maybe give the game more flavor. Obviously the game isn't there for a story, which is sad because. . .well I like story, the tale told in this one is generic and bland, and so are the characters. However the game is all around great, mainly because of all the awesome references, I mean how many games do you get to fly star-foxes ♥♥♥♥ and carry around clouds buster blade? None except this and maybe minecraft. It also had a decent boss fight at the end, and I wasn't at all disappointed by the battle, it wasn't super hard or anything but it was fun. The game is by no means hard, but defiantly has it's annoy parts, and despite it only being like a 2-4 hour game I've put more than double that into it, don't ask why, I don't know myself lol. Anyways good purchase I'd say it's worth the price if they lowered it by like three bucks. I think if a little bit more development would have been put into the combat, puzzles and story and not let references sell this game it may have been a 5 out of 5.

reviewText:
Did you play RPGs on the NES? SNES? Playstation 1? Then you will most likely enjoy Evoland. It's a charming adventure that will make you chuckle, smile and fondly remember the eras of past gaming - although if you never experienced them or weren't alive when these eras happened I imagine you won't be having much besides a blank stare throughout the entire thing. Thats the biggest point I can make - unless you have experienced these video game eras first hand, the humor and charm will seem nonexistant. If you buy it and expect to be taught a RPG history lesson you will be disappointed.

You play as the standard everyhero named Clink - an obvious amalgamation of Link and Cloud - the everyheroes of FF7 and Pre-OoT Zelda games. The main thing you'll be doing is finding technology upgrades that will advance the tech from black and white to color, from 8bit to 16bit, adding save points, health meters and much more.

Halfway through the game the tech advances appear less and less and it becomes more of a simple action AND turn-based RPG. But even in these later sections there are some interesting uses of switching between 8bit and 3D render modes to complete puzzles. It's nothing too difficult but overall a clever way of making challenges. My personal favorite area was the Diablo-clone
date: action RPG" stage complete with ridiculous loot drops. It's also the only area you can play as Kaeris(I wonder who shes based off of? /endsarcasm)\n\nThe story portion of the game only takes a few hours but there are some collectibles you can search for to extend your play time like Stars or Cards that you can use for the bonus card mini-game(more or less identical to FF8's Triple Triad). The game also has some pretty nice artwork and music - I've found myself humming tunes from the game long after completing it. Heck
recommended: I even payed for the soundtrack.\n\nI personally enjoyed this game and I got exactly what I thought I'd get by reading the tagline - a short story about the evolution of RPGs. That said considering the short length and the simplicity of the second half
hoursPlayed: $10 is a bit steep. Buy it on sale if you can."
